page.title: 09Farming
page.content: In 16th and 17th Centuries as the marsh was drained,oats and barley were the chief crops.Turf was a valuable asset and sold as fuel.Pota- toes were successfully grown eg 1784 the yield was 200-300 bushels per acre.Bread became the staple diet about 1800,it used to be oatcake.Dairy farming has increased throughout the last 200 years "Mosstocks" are still ploughed up on the areas from which peat has been taken,these are the remains of prehistoric oaks.More wheat was grown in the 19th century. You will see from the land use survey that most of the farmland is now in grass, either grazing or for silage.There is some barley grown as well as potatoes (Pilling's are highly regarded in Lancashire).Horticulture is in decline with the exception of "organically" grown crops such as tomatoes.
